elements.content: Assembly of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (Hpya·HCl) and Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, 3CdSO4·8H2O, or MnCl2·4H2O gave rise to five polymeric complexes {[Zn(C7H6NO2)2]·7H2O} n (1), [trans-M(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (M = Zn, 2; Cd, 3; Mn, 5), and [cis-Cd(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (4), respectively. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that complex 1 has a two-dimensional (2D) framework comprising rhombic grids of cavity dimensions 13.965 × 12.475 Å, and the structure is extended into a three-dimensional network with large unique quasi-aperture by hydrogen bond and π − π stacking interactions. Complexes 2, 3, and 5 possess a 2D structure consisting of alternate left and right helical chains with rhombic grids of dimensions 15.933 × 5.692, 16.445 × 5.834, and 16.179 × 5.706 Å, respectively. Complex 4 has a 2D network constructed by right helical chains. Different crystallization conditions result in different coordination geometries of metal centers in zinc (1 and 2) and cadmium complexes (3 and 4). Thermogravimetric analyses of the complexes were performed.

elements.content: Design and assembly of supramolecular architecture with variable cavities or channels are currently of great interest owing to their novel topologies and potential applications. Up to now, a great number of inorganic−organic hybrid coordination polymers have been synthesized based on covalent interactions or supramolecular connections such as hydrogen bond and/or π − π interactions. It has been documented that the geometries of organic ligands have a great effect on the structural frameworks of such coordination polymers; thus, much effort has been devoted to modify the building blocks and to control the assembled motifs for required products through the selection of different organic ligands. Previous studies have shown that rigid bridging ligands containing multi-carboxylate groups (Scheme a,b) or hybrid pyridyl/carboxylate groups (Scheme c,d) are versatile ligands for construction of the moderately robust networks and other porous coordination polymers. However, much fewer studies on coordination chemistry of flexible organic ligands contemporarily containing carboxylate group and pyridyl nitrogen atoms (Scheme e) have been carried out. 4-Pyridylacetic acid (Hpya) possesses two interesting characteristics:  (a) it possesses flexibility owing to the presence of a -CH2- spacer between the pyridyl ring and carboxylate moiety (Scheme e); (b) it holds three potential bonding sites, i.e., the nitrogen atom and two oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group. Because the carboxylate group can adopt monodentate, chelating-bidentate, bridging-bidentate, and bridging-multidentate modes, rich coordination modes of pya- may be expected. If pya- coordinates to metal ions through its pyridyl nitrogen atom and carboxylate group that adopts monodentate or chelating-bidentate mode, it may be used as monoanion μ2-bridging ligand. Accordingly, a grid-like structure may be expected by introducing metal ions favoring tetra- or hexa-coordination mode, and the flexibility of pya- may result in a novel framework. Herein we report the preparations and characterizations of five new polymeric complexes, {[Zn(C7H6NO2)2]·7H2O} n (1), [trans-M(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (M = Zn, 2; Cd, 3; Mn, 5), and [cis-Cd(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (4).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and assembly of supramolecular architecture with variable cavities or channels are currently of great interest owing to their novel topologies and potential applications. Up to now, a great number of inorganic-organic hybrid coordination polymers have been synthesized based on covalent interactions or supramolecular connections such as hydrogen bond and/or π - π interactions. It has been documented that the geometries of organic ligands have a great effect on the structural frameworks of such coordination polymers; thus, much effort has been devoted to modify the building blocks and to control the assembled motifs for required products through the selection of different organic ligands. Previous studies have shown that rigid bridging ligands containing multi-carboxylate groups (Scheme a,b) or hybrid pyridyl/carboxylate groups (Scheme c,d) are versatile ligands for construction of the moderately robust networks and other porous coordination polymers. However, much fewer studies on coordination chemistry of flexible organic ligands contemporarily containing carboxylate group and pyridyl nitrogen atoms (Scheme e) have been carried out. 4-Pyridylacetic acid (Hpya) possesses two interesting characteristics: (a) it possesses flexibility owing to the presence of a -CH2- spacer between the pyridyl ring and carboxylate moiety (Scheme e); (b) it holds three potential bonding sites, i.e., the nitrogen atom and two oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group. Because the carboxylate group can adopt monodentate, chelating-bidentate, bridging-bidentate, and bridging-multidentate modes, rich coordination modes of pya- may be expected. If pya- coordinates to metal ions through its pyridyl nitrogen atom and carboxylate group that adopts monodentate or chelating-bidentate mode, it may be used as monoanion μ2-bridging ligand. Accordingly, a grid-like structure may be expected by introducing metal ions favoring tetra- or hexa-coordination mode, and the flexibility of pya- may result in a novel framework. Herein we report the preparations and characterizations of five new polymeric complexes, {[Zn(C7H6NO2)2]⋅7H2O} n  (1), [trans-M(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n  (M = Zn, 2; Cd, 3; Mn, 5), and [cis-Cd(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n  (4).

Preparation of Complexes. {[Zn(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 ]·7H 2 O} n (1). A mixture of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (20 mL) was heated (80−90 °C) and stirred for 20 min. A few drops of 0.1 M NaOH aqueous solution were added to adjust the pH value to 6, and the resulting mixture was filtered. Colorless single crystals were obtained after two weeks (yields:  80% based on C7H7NO2·HCl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for C14H26N2O11Zn (463.74):  C, 36.26; H, 5.65; N, 6.04. Found (%):  C, 36.12; H, 5.57; N, 5.94. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3521(vs), 3442(vs), 3265(s), 1653(m), 1626(vs), 1597(vs), 1439(s), 1387(vs), 1348(w), 1290(s), 1209(w), 1070(w), 939(w), 754(w), 698(m), 648(m), 592(w), and 476(w).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Data collection for 1−5 was performed on a Siemens SMART-CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. All absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, the metal atoms were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were derived from the successive difference Fourier Syntheses. The hydrogen atoms were located from the difference map and refined isotropically. The structure was refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL-97 program package on a legend computer. The crystallographic data of complexes 1−5 are listed in Table and the selected bond lengths and angles are in Table . Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for complexes 1−5 have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publications.

elements.content: Physical Measurements. The infrared spectra were taken on a Magna 750 FTIR spectrophotometer as KBr pellets in the 4000−400 cm-1 regions. The elementary analyses were performed in this institute. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851e instrument. Crystalline samples of 1 were heated from room temperature to 850 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen, and crystalline samples of 2, 3, 4, and 5 were heated from room temperature to 650 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen. XRPD data for 1−4 were collected on Xpert MPD diffractometer at room temperature.

elements.content: Syntheses of Complexes. Through solution reactions of 4-pyridylacetic acid (Hpya) and M2+ (M = Zn, Cd, and Mn), five coordination polymeric complexes were successfully isolated. In aqueous solution (pH = 6), the reaction of Hpya and Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O in a mole ratio of 3/2 with stirring and heating (80−90°C) gave rise to a colorless mixture, and complex 1 is obtained in 80% yield after standing the mixture in air for several days. The coordination environment of zinc ion in 1 is tetrahedron (Scheme a). Interestingly, when the same reaction was run by a layer-separating diffusion method without heating, complex 2, in which zinc ion adopts octahedral coordination geometry (Scheme b), was isolated in 60% yield. A similar phenomenon was observed in the cadmium system. When the reaction of Hpya and 3CdSO4·8H2O in a mole ratio of 3/1 was performed with stirring and heating (80−90°C) in water (pH = 6), complex 3 having the cadmium ion in octahedral geometry with coordinated water molecules occupying the trans-positions (Scheme b) was isolated in 75% yield. Whereas when the same reaction was carried out by a layer-separating diffusion method without heating, complex 4, where the coordinated water molecules occupy the cis-positions of the octahedron around the cadmium ion (Scheme c), was isolated in 60% yield. The purity of complexes 1−4 is confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction analyses, in which the lattice parameters derived from XRPD data are almost consistent with those obtained by single crystal X-ray diffraction. For the case of manganese, only complex 5 with the coordinated waters occupying the trans-positions of the octahedron around manganese ion (Scheme b) was obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses of Complexes. Through solution reactions of 4-pyridylacetic acid (Hpya) and M2+ (M = Zn, Cd, and Mn), five coordination polymeric complexes were successfully isolated. In aqueous solution (pH = 6), the reaction of Hpya and Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O in a mole ratio of 3/2 with stirring and heating (80-90°C) gave rise to a colorless mixture, and complex 1 is obtained in 80% yield after standing the mixture in air for several days. The coordination environment of zinc ion in 1 is tetrahedron (Scheme a). Interestingly, when the same reaction was run by a layer-separating diffusion method without heating, complex 2, in which zinc ion adopts octahedral coordination geometry (Scheme b), was isolated in 60% yield. A similar phenomenon was observed in the cadmium system. When the reaction of Hpya and 3CdSO4⋅8H2O in a mole ratio of 3/1 was performed with stirring and heating (80-90°C) in water (pH = 6), complex 3 having the cadmium ion in octahedral geometry with coordinated water molecules occupying the trans-positions (Scheme b) was isolated in 75% yield. Whereas when the same reaction was carried out by a layer-separating diffusion method without heating, complex 4, where the coordinated water molecules occupy the cis-positions of the  octahedron around the cadmium ion (Scheme c), was isolated in 60% yield. The purity of complexes 1-4 is confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction analyses, in which the lattice parameters derived from XRPD data are almost consistent with those obtained by single crystal X-ray diffraction. For the case of manganese, only complex 5 with the coordinated waters occupying the trans-positions of the octahedron around manganese ion (Scheme b) was obtained.

In similar reaction systems of rigid pyridyl carboxylates, such as 4-pyridylcarboxylate, no cis-configuration of octahedral coordination geometry of cadmium ion is observed, and only a few tetrahedral coordination geometries of zinc ion are reported. Hence, the variety of coordination geometries around Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions in this work may result from the presence of the -CH2- spacer between the pyridyl ring and carboxylate moiety of pya- ligand, and the flexibility makes the ligand adjustable to meet the geometric requirements of different coordination configurations of metal ions.

elements.content: The different coordination geometries of metal centers in the complexes are understandable. According to the valence bond theory, the valence electronic structure of zinc(II) ion is 3d104s0, and the zinc ion can take sp3 or sp3d2 hybrid and thereby exhibits tetrahedral or octahedral coordination geometry. For the zinc ion, due to its comparatively small radius, steric hindrance may play an important role. Thus, complex 1, with less steric hindrance around the zinc center than that in 2, is isolated with heating. For cadmium, trans- and cis-octahedral coordination fashions are observed in 3 and 4. This may result from the fact that the cadmium ion has a larger radius than that of the zinc ion; the effect of steric hindrance of ligands becomes less important, and thus, the cadmium ion can afford cis-conformation under mild reaction conditions but trans-conformation under heating conditions (80−90 °C). For the manganese ion, the unoccupied 3d orbit has a similar energy level to 4p orbit, and its electronic structure favors d2sp3 hybrid rather than sp3 hybrid, and thereby only octahedral coordination fashion of manganese in 5 (Scheme b) is observed, and the small atomic radius may render the formation of cis-conformation compound as in 4.

This may result from the fact that the cadmium ion has a larger radius than that of the zinc ion; the effect of steric hindrance of ligands becomes less important, and thus, the cadmium ion can afford cis-conformation under mild reaction conditions but trans-conformation under heating conditions (80-90 °C). elements.content: The theoretical calculation is carried out using the semiempirical method PM3 from Gaussian 98W program. The single point calculation exhibits that the total energy of the octahedral trans-configuration in 3 is lower by 29.20 kJ/mol than that of the octahedral cis-configuration in 4, indicating that 3 is thermodynamically more stable than 4. For zinc compounds, the cis-configuration of octahedral coordination geometry of zinc ion is finally optimized to be the tetrahedral configuration, in which the total energy is lower by 26.84 kJ/mol than that of the octahedral trans-configuration in 2. This result is consistent with the experimental data that no cis-configuration of octahedral coordination zinc compound is isolated. For the manganese(II) system, the cis-configuration of octahedral coordination geometry is optimized, and its total energy is higher by 120.57 kJ/mol than that of the octahedral trans-configuration in 5. The result shows that the cis-configuration of octahedral coordination geometry of Mn(II) ion is thermodynamically much less stable than the trans-configuration compound and thereby is not obtained from the synthetic experiments.

elements.content: To confirm the above discussions, auxiliary experiments were carried out. When the pH value of a slurry of 2 in water is adjusted to 2, complex 2 is dissolved gradually under stirring and heating (80−90 °C). After the pH value is adjusted to 6, only complex 1 is recrystallized, indicating that complex 2 is completely reconstructed into complex 1. Similarly, complex 4 can be dissolved in hot water (pH = 2) and only 3 is recystallized (pH = 6), exhibiting that complex 4 is completely reconstructed into complex 3. The reconstruction of the structures of zinc and cadmium complexes is irreversible. For manganese complex 5, no structure change is observed. These results probably differ from previous claims of structure transformation, and confirm our discussions that are also supported by TGA studies (see below).

elements.content: Description of Crystal Structures. {[Zn(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 ] · 7H 2 O} n (1). Single X-ray analysis reveals complex 1 possesses two-dimensional (2D) framework constructed by Zn(II) centers and pya- ligands. The local coordination environment around zinc(II) ion (Figure ) shows that each four-coordinate zinc center is in a slightly distorted tetrahedron formed by two identical carboxylate groups in monodentate fashion (Zn−O = 1.966 (3) Å) and two pyridine nitrogen atoms (Zn−N = 2.046(3) Å). Each pya- ligand in 1 alternately employs its carboxylate oxygen atom and pyridine nitrogen atom to coordinate to two zinc ions, and each zinc center connects four pya- ligands. Thus, four zinc ions and four pya- ligands form a noncoplanar tetragon with side length 9.363 Å and a diagonal measurement about 13.965 × 12.475 Å based on the metal−metal distances. The four zinc ions lie in the same plane; each subtense pya- ligands stand up and down the plane. The non-coplanar shape of the tetragon is understandable, because the sp3 hybrid configuration of C atom of the -CH2- spacer forces the pya- ligand to be nonlinear, generating the nonlinear sides (actually, the C(1)−C(2)−C(3) angle of the pya- ligand is 114.8(3)°). Such a macrocyclic tetragon is further extended through the pya- ligand and metal ions into a 2D network with rhombic grids (Figure ).

elements.content: The most intriguing feature of the structure for 1 is that there is not interpenetration between adjacent layers. Interestingly, zinc(II) ions and pya- ligands form cross arch bridges in two perpendicular directions in the same layer, the benzene rings of one layers parallel to those of the adjacent layers to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework with unique quasi-apertures (Figure ) by hydrogen bonding and the face to face π − π stacking interactions of the aromatic rings of neighboring layers with distances from 3.40 to 3.54 Å. Such quasi-apertures allow accommodating a great number of guest water molecules, yielding a variety of hydrogen bonds, and in turn enhance the stability of the apertures.1, 25 The crystal structure of 1 is similar to previous works that do not have interpenetrations between adjacent layers and can provide large void spaces to accommodate solvent molecules or ions, but it is very different from those with diverse interpenetrations filling the void space.

The tetragon formed by four pya- ligands and four Zn ions has a side length 8.459 Å and a diagonal measurement of 15.933 × 5.692 Å based on the metal−metal distances. elements.content: trans -[Cd(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] n (3). Complex 3 has a 2D structure, which crystallizes in space group P2(1)/n, comprising infinite layers of interchanging Cd(II) cations and ligand pya- anions. A view of the metal ion coordination in 3 is shown in Figure , where the metal center is coordinated by two monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd−O = 2.289(6) Å), two pyridine nitrogen atoms (Cd−N = 2.339(7) Å), and two water molecules (Cd−O = 2.336(7) Å) in an octahedral geometry. Two nitrogen atoms occupy the axial positions and four oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane with all of the bond angles of Ocarboxylate−Cd−Ocarboxylate, Owater−Cd−Owater, and N−Cd−N being 180°. Two coordination water molecules and two carboxylate oxygen atoms stand at trans-positions (Scheme b), respectively. Each pya- utilizes its pyridine nitrogen and carboxylate oxygen to connect two Cd(II) ions. Four pya- ligands and four Cd(II) ions form a tetragon with a side length of 8.725 Å and a diagonal measurement of 16.445 × 5.834 Å based on the metal−metal distances. The tetragon is further extended to a 2D framework with a rhombic grid through sharing Cd(II) ions and pya- ligands (Figure a). The elongated grids in 3, different from those in 1, have small void spaces, which cannot accommodate any solvent molecules.

elements.content: The distinguishing earmark of complex 3 is that it possesses two kinds of helical structures, in which left helical chains and right helical chains are in an alternate array and are further extended into a 2D framework through sharing metal ions (Figure b). All Cd ions of each layer are coplanar, and the distance of adjacent layers consisting of metal ions is about 7.877 Å. Through van der Waals forces between neighboring layers, the 2D structure is further extended into the final 3D network along the b axis (Figure ). It should be noted that the actual structure of the 2D layer is wavelike; the convex surface of one layer is perched on the concave surface of the adjacent layer to get a tightly packed structure without any guest molecules.

cis -[Cd(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] n (4). Complex 4, crystallizing in the chiral space group C 2, is the conformational isomer of 3. The coordination geometry of the center metal ion is a greatly distorted octahedron (Figure and Scheme c), in which two nitrogen atoms occupy the axial positions (Cd−N = 2.325(14) Å) and four oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane with Cd−Owater = 2.337(16) Å; Cd−Ocarboxylate = 2.276(15) Å. In equatorial plane, two water molecules and two carboxylate oxygen atoms are located in cis-sites, respectively. The bond angles of Ocarboxylate−Cd−Ocarboxylate and Owater−Cd−Owater are 105.3(9)° and 76.8(9)°, respectively. The distortion may come from the larger steric hindrance of the cis-configuration of 4 as compared to 3.

elements.content: Four cadmium ions and four pya- ligands form a tetragon with a side length of 8.705 Å and a diagonal measurement of 16.403 × 5.834 Å based on the metal−metal distances. The grid-like Cd4(pya)4 species can be viewed as the basic building block of the structure, where the apices are occupied by cadmium ions and the sides are formed by pya- ligands. Such Cd4(pya)4 grids are joined together through sharing the cadmium apices and the pya- sides to give the 2D layer framework in the bc plane (Figure ). In the 2D structure of 4, all Cd ions of each layer are coplanar, and all coordination water molecules fall on the same side of the plane consisting of the metal ions, which different from the case in 3. The distance of the adjacent metal layer is about 7.870 Å. Interestingly, in 4 the pya- ligands only form right helical chains by crunodes of Cd(II) ions. The right helical chains are extended through sharing metal ions into a 2D network, which is different from the alternate array of left helical and right helical chains in 3.

elements.content: trans -[Mn(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] n (5). The crystal structure of 5 is isomorphous to that of 2 or 3. The local coordination environment around Mn(II) ion is shown in Figure , where the coordination geometry of Mn(II) ion is a slightly distorted octahedron, two nitrogen atoms occupy the axial positions (Mn−N = 2.281(2) Å), and four oxygen atoms stand in the equatorial plane with bond distances of Mn−Owater = 2.189(2) Å, Mn−Ocarboxylate = 2.185(2) Å. Since the radius of the Mn(II) ion is slightly smaller than that of the Cd(II) ion, all of the metal−ligand bonds in 5 are slightly shorter than the corresponding bonds in 3. The tetragon formed by four pya- ligands and four Mn ions demonstrates a side length of 8.578 Å and a diagonal measurement of 16.179 × 5.706 Å based on the metal−metal distances. The distance of adjacent layer consisting of metal ions is about 7.845 Å.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA). TGA of complex 1 was performed under a flow of nitrogen gas from room temperature to 850 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min. The first weight loss of 26.67% (calcd:  27.20%) from 58 to 130 °C corresponds to the loss of seven water molecules per formula unit (7H2O/{[Zn(pya)2]·7H2O}. The final weight 73.33% (Calcd:  72.80%) corresponds to a framework of [Zn(pya)2]. Decomposition of the complex begins at 195 °C and ends at 464 °C. The final decomposed product, presumably ZnCO3 (based on the remaining mass), was found to be amorphous by XRPD, which hardly loses any weight upon further heating from 464 to 850°C. TGA for complexes 2−5 have also been measured under a flow of nitrogen gas from room temperature to 650 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. All the TGA data are listed in Table .

elements.content: In conclusion, by selecting a flexible bridging ligand 4-pyridylacetic acid, five polymeric complexes, {[Zn(C7H6NO2)2]·7H2O} n (1), [trans-M(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (M = Zn, 2; Cd, 3; Mn, 5), and [cis-Cd(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (4), were successfully isolated as crystalline forms under different crystallization conditions. Complex 1 has a 2D framework comprising rhombic grids, and the structure is further extended into a 3D network with large unique quasi-aperture by hydrogen bonding and π − π stacking interactions. Complexes 2, 3, and 5 possess a 2D structure consisting of alternate left and right helical chains. Complex 4 has a 2D network constructed by right helical chains. The work reported herein may provide useful information for the construction of infinite frameworks by flexible ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, by selecting a flexible bridging ligand 4-pyridylacetic acid, five polymeric complexes, {[Zn(C7H6NO2)2]⋅7H2O} n  (1), [trans-M(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n  (M = Zn, 2; Cd, 3; Mn, 5), and [cis-Cd(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n   (4), were successfully isolated as crystalline forms under different crystallization conditions. Complex 1 has a 2D framework comprising rhombic grids, and the structure is further extended into a 3D network with large unique quasi-aperture by hydrogen bonding and π - π stacking interactions. Complexes 2, 3, and 5 possess a 2D structure consisting of alternate left and right helical chains. Complex 4 has a 2D network constructed by right helical chains. The work reported herein may provide useful information for the construction of infinite frameworks by flexible ligands.

Preparation of Complexes. {[Zn(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 ]·7H 2 O} n (1). A mixture of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (20 mL) was heated (80−90 °C) and stirred for 20 min. A few drops of 0.1 M NaOH aqueous solution were added to adjust the pH value to 6, and the resulting mixture was filtered. Colorless single crystals were obtained after two weeks (yields:  80% based on C7H7NO2·HCl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for C14H26N2O11Zn (463.74):  C, 36.26; H, 5.65; N, 6.04. Found (%):  C, 36.12; H, 5.57; N, 5.94. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3521(vs), 3442(vs), 3265(s), 1653(m), 1626(vs), 1597(vs), 1439(s), 1387(vs), 1348(w), 1290(s), 1209(w), 1070(w), 939(w), 754(w), 698(m), 648(m), 592(w), and 476(w).

trans -[Zn(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] n (2). The pH value of an aqueous solution (10 mL) of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol) was adjusted to 6.0 using NaOH. Then, a solution of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL) was carefully layered on it. After the sample stood for 2 days, colorless sheetlike crystals were obtained. (Yield:  60%, based on C7H7NO2·HCl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for C14H16N2O6Zn (373.66):  C, 45.00; H, 4.32; N, 7.50. Found (%):  C, 44.63; H, 4.27; N, 7.41. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3215(s), 1616(s), 1579(vs), 1444(m), 1425(s), 1365(vs), 1244(w), 1225(m), 1138(w), 1090(w), 1022(m), 814(m), 766(m), 675(m), 652(s), 544(w), and 501(w).

trans -[Cd(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] n (3). The pH value of a mixture of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol) and 3CdSO4·8H2O (0.077 g, 0.1 mmol) in H2O (20 mL) was adjusted to 6.0 using 0.1 M NaOH with heating (80−90°C) and vigorous stirring, and then the resulting mixture was filtered and allowed to evaporate at room temperature for a week, colorless crystals were isolated (yields:  75%, based on C7H7NO2·HCl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for C14H16CdN2O6 (420.69):  C, 39.97; H, 3.83; N, 6.66. Found (%):  C, 39.82; H, 3.76; N, 6.54. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3041(s), 1955(w), 1614(s), 1583(vs), 1556(s), 1446(w), 1427(s), 1358(vs), 1244(w), 1225(m), 1134(w), 1020(w), 812(m), 764(m), 652(s), 540(w), and 499(w).

cis -[Cd(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] n (4). The pH value of an aqueous solution (10 mL) of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol) was adjusted to 6.0 using 0.1 M NaOH. Then, a solution of 3CdSO4·8H2O (0.054 g, 0.07 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL) was carefully layered on it. After the sample stood for 2 days, colorless sheetlike crystals were obtained. (Yield:  60%, based on C7H7NO2·HCl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for C14H16CdN2O6 (420.69):  C, 39.97; H, 3.83; N, 6.66. Found (%):  C, 39.91; H, 3.74; N, 6.57. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3081(s), 1614(s), 1585(vs), 1504(w), 1446(w), 1427(m), 1360(s), 1244(w), 1225(w), 1136(w), 1020(w), 812(m), 764(w), 652(s), 542(w), and 499(w).

trans -[Mn(C 7 H 6 NO 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] n (5). The pH value of an aqueous solution (15 mL) of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol) was adjusted to 6, then solid MnCl2·4H2O (0.04 g. 0.2 mmol) was added with vigorous stirring and heating (80−90°C) for 15 min and allowed to evaporate at room temperature. After 10 days, colorless needlelike crystals were separated by filtration (yields:  80%, based on C7H7NO2·HCl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for C14H16MnN2O6 (363.23):  C, 46.29; H, 4.44; N, 7.71. Found (%):  C, 46.28; H, 4.28; N, 7.65. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3234(m), 1955(w), 1682(w), 1581(vs), 1400(s), 1362(vs), 1018(w), 812(m), 650(s), and 542(w).

cln_elements.content:
Assembly of 4-pyridylacetic acid hydrochloride (Hpya·HCl) and Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, 3CdSO4·8H2O, or MnCl2·4H2O gave rise to five polymeric complexes {[Zn(C7H6NO2)2]·7H2O} n (1), [trans-M(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (M = Zn, 2; Cd, 3; Mn, 5), and [cis-Cd(C7H6NO2)2(H2O)2] n (4), respectively. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that complex 1 has a two-dimensional (2D) framework comprising rhombic grids of cavity dimensions 13.965 × 12.475 Å, and the structure is extended into a three-dimensional network with large unique quasi-aperture by hydrogen bond and π − π stacking interactions. Complexes 2, 3, and 5 possess a 2D structure consisting of alternate left and right helical chains with rhombic grids of dimensions 15.933 × 5.692, 16.445 × 5.834, and 16.179 × 5.706 Å, respectively. Complex 4 has a 2D network constructed by right helical chains. Different crystallization conditions result in different coordination geometries of metal centers in zinc (1 and 2) and cadmium complexes (3 and 4). Thermogravimetric analyses of the complexes were performed.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA). TGA of complex 1 was performed under a flow of nitrogen gas from room temperature to 850 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min. The first weight loss of 26.67% (calcd:  27.20%) from 58 to 130 °C corresponds to the loss of seven water molecules per formula unit (7H2O/{[Zn(pya)2]·7H2O}. The final weight 73.33% (Calcd:  72.80%) corresponds to a framework of [Zn(pya)2]. Decomposition of the complex begins at 195 °C and ends at 464 °C. The final decomposed product, presumably ZnCO3 (based on the remaining mass), was found to be amorphous by XRPD, which hardly loses any weight upon further heating from 464 to 850°C. TGA for complexes 2−5 have also been measured under a flow of nitrogen gas from room temperature to 650 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. All the TGA data are listed in Table .
